Dear Brandon Hannah:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• Indicate how continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 204-6992.
Sincerely,
Cassandra Thomas, LMSW

INVESTIGATION:
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4112 Criminal history check, subject to requirements;
Section staff qualifications. (4)(a): A person with ongoing duties shall have both of
Description the following:(a) Ability to perform duties of the position assigned.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation On 11/26/22, youth were asking a staff member about their tattoo's.
Staff member pulled their pants lower on their hip to show the youth
one of the tattoo's. Youth did not see any genitalia or the buttocks, but
one youth felt uncomfortable.
Investigation On 11/29/2022 an in-person meeting was held with Staff 4 at Vassar
House. He provided information regarding the youth that were present
in the cabin the day of the alleged incident. Staff 4 also provided
2

copies of the face sheets for youth that would potentially be interviewed
by DCWL.
On 11/29/2022 an in-person interview with Youth A was completed at
Vassar House. She confirmed that the alleged incident occurred on
Saturday 11/26/2022. She stated it was about 11am and after lunch
time. She reported that her and other youth were sitting in the unit
talking and Youth C asked Staff 2 if she had any tattoos. Staff 2
responded that she had two and proceeded to show the youth her
tattoos. Youth A reported that she first showed the tattoo on her ankle
and then showed the one on her hip. Youth A reported that Staff 2 had
to lift her shirt and fold down her pants in order to show off her tattoo.
Youth A reported that she began to feel uncomfortable. Youth A further
reported that she felt that Staff 2 had bad boundaries with the youth.
She reported that Staff 2 let the youth play with her hair, walk arm and
arm with them, and horse plays with the youth. Lastly, Youth A
reported that Staff 1 has worn socks to work that had pictures of
marijuana on them and told the youth that there is nothing “bad” about
it.
On 11/29/2022 an in-person interview with Youth B was completed at
Vassar House. She reported that Youth C asked Staff 1 if she had a
tattoo. Staff 1 said yes and asked the youth if they wanted to see it.
Youth B recalled that the youth said “yes” and Staff 1 lifted her shirt to
show one tattoo. Youth B did not recall if Staff 1 had to pull her pants
down to show the second tattoo. Youth B reported that she did see
skin and it made her a little uncomfortable.
On 11/29/2022 an in-person interview with Youth C was completed at
Vassar House. She reported that Staff 1 came to the unit, and they
were discussing tattoos. Youth B asked Staff 1 if she had any tattoos
and asked to see them. She reported that Staff 1 showed one on her
ankle and one on her hip. She recalled that Staff 1 had to lift her shirt
and pull her pants down a little to show the second tattoo. She
described the tattoo as being on “her hip” but denies that it made her
nervous.
On 11/29/2022 an in-person interview with Staff 2 was completed at
Vassar House. She denied being present for the tattoo incident. She
further denied knowledge of inappropriate boundaries by Staff 1 with
youth. She also denied that any of the youth reported to her that the
incident made them feel uncomfortable.
On 11/29/2022 an in-person interview with Staff 3 was completed at
Vassar House. She recalled being in the unit on the day of the alleged
incident. She stated that four or five of the youth were in her area
4

watching TV and the rest were over near Staff 1. She denied seeing
Staff 1 show the youth any tattoos.
On 12/05/2022 a telephone call was made to complainant. No
additional concerns were noted.
On 12/05/2022 an in-person interview with Staff 1 was completed at
Vassar House. She confirmed that she was on shift and in the unit
when the alleged incident occurred. She reported that Staff 2 was also
in the unit. Staff 1 confirmed that she did show the youth the tattoo on
her ankle but denied that she showed the tattoo on her hip. She stated
that she motioned with her hand on the outer area of her clothing in her
hip area. Staff 1 reported she does not know why the youth would
report that she lifted her shirt or pulled her pants down to show the
tattoo on her hip. Staff 1 also denied wearing socks that showed
marijuana on them to work.
The Wolverine Human Service communication policy was reviewed.
The policy documents that any unauthorized contact of staff with youth
is considered inappropriate and a violation of the policy. It specifically
indicates that written letters, notes, or any form of electronic
communication is prohibited.
Analysis At the conclusion of the investigation, there was sufficient evidence to
find the agency in non-compliance with licensing rule 400.4112 (4)(a).
Multiple youth interviewed reported that Staff 1 showed off her tattoos
and a second one was at or below her hip line. Staff 1 admitted to
engaging in discussion with the youth regarding tattoos and admitting to
showing at least one of her tattoos to the youth.
Conclusion Repeat Violation Established
2022C0137034 dated 09/20/22, CAP Approval date 01/13/2022
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4109(1)(c): (1) An institution shall have and follow a
Section current written program statement which specifically addresses all of
Description the following: (c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care,
safety, and supervision, methods for addressing residents’ needs,
implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of residents.
Violation Additional Findings
Type
Allegation Staff was communicating with youth in the program via social media
and sharing her personal contact information.
4

Investigation On 11/29/2022 an in-person interview with Youth A was completed at
Vassar House. Youth A reported that she overheard Staff 1 talking with
Youth C in person while in the unit. She told Youth C that she had
looked her up on Instagram and found her picture.
On 11/29/2022 an in-person interview with Youth B was completed at
Vassar House. Youth B reported that Youth C passed Staff 1 a note
with information for her to post on Instagram for her. Youth B reported
that she believed that Staff 1 would post messages to the boyfriend of
Youth C’s social media sites. Youth B was unable to provide additional
information as to how she knew this to be accurate.
On 11/29/2022 an in-person interview with Youth C was completed at
Vassar House. Youth C reported that once when she had court and
thought that she was going to get escalated, Staff 1 asked her for her
Instagram information, and she provided it. Youth C reported that on
another occasion Staff 1 asked her if she wanted a favor. Youth C
stated that she responded “yes” and that Staff 1 agreed to post a
message on the social media account of her boyfriend. Youth C
reported that she wrote the message on paper and gave it to Staff 1.
Youth C reported that Staff 1 told her that she could not tell anyone.
Youth C reported asking Staff 1 if she had posted the message for her
yet and she responded, “not yet”.
On 12/05/2022 an in-person interview of Staff 1 was completed at
Vassar House. Staff 1 denied communicating with the youth of the
agency via social media and denied that she had communicated
anything with family or friends of any youth via social media.
The Wolverine Human Service communication policy was reviewed.
The policy documents that any unauthorized contact of staff with youth
is considered inappropriate and a violation of the policy. It specifically
indicates that written letters, notes, or any form of electronic
communication is prohibited.
Analysis At the conclusion of the investigation, there was sufficient evidence to
support that the agency was in non-compliance with licensing rule
400.4109 (1)(c). Staff 1 was communicating with Youth C in a manner
that was prohibited in the communication policy of the agency.
Conclusion Repeat Violation Established

2022C0137036 dated 09/19/22, CAP Approval date: 10/13/2022

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on the findings of this investigation, in conjunction with the recommendation
of SIR 2023C0137003, a First Provisional license is recommended upon receipt on
an acceptable corrective action plan.
